section.text: Nonharmonic tones (or non-chord tones) are notes that do not belong in a certain chord.
In the above example, the F is a nonharmonic tone because it does not fit into the I chord (which contains C, E, and G).
Before we can discuss the different types of nonharmonic tones, two terms must be defined.
A step is equal to an interval of a generic second.
A skip is equal to an interval of a generic third or more.
Now we can proceed to learn the various nonharmonic tones.
A passing tone (PT) is approached by step and then continues by step in the same direction.
If a passing tone occurs with the second chord (instead of in the middle of the two chords), it is called an accented passing tone (>PT).
Listen to the above examples.
A neighboring tone (NT) is approached by step and then returns by step to the original note.
If it occurs with the second chord, it is called an accented neighboring tone (>NT).
Listen to the above examples.
An escape tone (ET) is approached by step and then skips in the opposite direction.
Escape tones are not accented. They occur in between the two chords.
Listen to the above example.
An appoggiatura (App.) is the exact opposite. It is approached by skip and then steps in the opposite direction.
Also, appoggiaturas are accented. They will occur with the second chord.
Listen to the above example.
An anticipation (Ant.) is approached by step and then remains the same. It is basically a note of the second chord played early.
Anticipations are unaccented.
Listen to the above examples.
The next two nonharmonic tones are the opposite of an anticipation. They sustain a note from the first chord.
A retardation (Ret.) keeps a note the same and then steps upward.
A suspension (Sus.) keeps a note the same and then steps downward.
It should be noted that both the retardation and the suspension are accented nonharmonic tones.
Listen to the above examples.
Finally, a changing tone (CT) is actually two nonharmonic tones.
The first nonharmonic tone is approached by step and then jumps a generic third to the second nonharmonic tone.
The second nonharmonic tone then resolves by step.
Listen to the above examples.
